results.title: Billycarts
results.brief_description: This evocative silent home movie footage shows kids playing in a billycart in the drive-way and on the street, and creates a strong nostalgia for long ago youth. Athol Adams footage is courtesy of Jenny and Owen Peake.

results.title: 30 Seconds to go
results.brief_description:
Shot at a Mildura television station. Details how an episode of ‘On the Land’ is broadcast by inter-cutting between an installment of the programme and conventional ‘behind the scenes’ footage of a television studio. This includes shots of a camera operator, the television station’s studio, vision-switching and so on.

Actual ‘On the Land’ programme featured, contains information on good seeds to sow and non-hormonal spraying techniques. Contains exterior shots of an orchid.

Film opens with exterior shots of Mildura that begin at river and then move into more general street scenes. This lasts for two minutes.

results.title: Alice Moyle
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: on music”.
Alice Moyle was born in South Africa on 25th December 1908 and spent her first four years there before migrating out to Australia with her parents. She learned the piano and studied music at school, attending the University of Melbourne Conservatorium where she graduated with a Bachelor of Music in 1930. Alice Moyle’s first experience of Aboriginal music was listening to recordings made by Professor Elkin when she was attending courses at the Faculty of Music at Sydney University. These recordings were to prepare teachers for work in the outback. In 1959 Alice made the first of many field trips into the outback to continue the process of recording and archiving Aboriginal music. She has continually tried to inspire others with her experiences and knowledge in Aboriginal music and culture and is adamant that music be included as an essential component in the study of Aboriginal culture. This documentary is a recorded interview between Alice Moyle and James Murdoch.

group.title: Australia Council archival film series: on music

results.title: Peter Sculthorpe
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: on music”.
Peter Sculthorpe, Australia’s best-known contemporary composer, discusses his personal philosophy and the influences which have shaped his creative development. Sculthorpe studied at the Melbourne University Conservatorium of Music and at Oxford University. His “Sonatina for Piano” was performed at the International Society of Contemporary Music Festival in Baden-Baden in 1955 and he went on to receive international recognition with the success of his Sun Music series. Throughout his career, Sculthorpe has drawn on a diversity of cultural influences in his quest to develop uniquely Australian music. He has composed for film, television, theatre and opera as well as the concert platform, and enjoys the status of elder statesman among contemporary Australian composers. A performance of his work “Kakadu” in 1989 was a rallying point for Australian conservationists and since then Sculthorpe has used his music to promote environmental causes. Research and interview: James Murdoch.

results.title: Astronomy: an Open Learning unit
results.creator_credit: Michael Hollander, Monash University, Open University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: This astronomy series features the southern skies particularly the work being done in Australia by scientists and astronomers who are trying to unravel the secrets of the universe. These programs are part of an Open Learning unit and can be viewed in conjunction with the series entitled “Universe: the infinite frontier.”
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Hollander, Monash University, Open University and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: A Watch on the southern sky
results.creator_credit: Michael Hollander, ABC-TV (Australia), Open Learning Agency of Australia and Monash University
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Astronomy: an Open Learning unit”.
Provides a brief history of astronomy and a look at constellations. The program then focuses on how to map the sky and determine the location of celestial objects as well as looking at the differences between stars in terms of magnitude, colour and position. Examines the Moon and its cycles, and the location of planets in the night sky.

results.title: Australia and the stars
results.creator_credit: Michael Hollander, Open Learning Agency of Australia, Monash University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Astronomy: an Open Learning unit”.
The Southern Hemisphere provides some of the best viewing for astronomers. Galaxies and Nebulae close to the Southern Cross constellation are more observable and provide useful data to astronomers studying the wonders of the universe. This program also provides a brief history of astronomy from a Southern Hemisphere perspective by highlighting Captain Cook’s voyage to Australia.

results.title: Looking up down under
results.creator_credit: Michael Hollander, ABC-TV (Australia), Open Learning Agency of Australia and Monash University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Astronomy: an Open Learning unit”.
Telescopes provide our gateway to the stars. The study of astronomy relies heavily on telescopes and has done so for many centuries. Australia is in a unique position for studying the heavens, given its location in the Southern Hemisphere and its relatively small population. This program looks at the history of Astronomy in Australia.

results.title: From the heart
results.creator_credit: SBS Independent, ACMI and Hossein Valamanesh
results.brief_description: Using 35mm footage capturing his own angiogram, Hossein Valamanesh creates a mysterious, luminescent universe which hovers, like a heartbeat, between biology and the sublime.
